data.title: Go For The View
data.text: Primo has just undergone a Head Chef change.  The menu seems very limited at this time, possibly due to the new chef.  Obviously, this is a place to go for very special occasions when you want a romantic setting and to drink alcoholic beverages.  As for the food, I was not all that impressed.  I had calamari, which was actually very good, and the sauce had a little kick to it.  I also had the house Caesar salad, but the dressing was not very flavorful.  One friend had the house salad and she said it was drowning in the Italian dressing and she could not eat it.  Two others had the Chicken Marsala and they said it was good, just not a lot for the money.  Another had the filet entrée.  She said it was very tasty and it came with two sides.  There was a large group there at the tables next to us for a 15 year old's birthday.  There was about 20+ of them, and they were extremely loud, so it took away from our hopes of a nice quiet evening.  The offer valet parking for $6.  Best bet by far, as other parking is several blocks away and you will not want to walk back to your car after dark.  All in all, I can say it was an OK experience, but will probably not be going back.

data.title: Perfect Meal Beyond Expectations
data.text: I can’t thank Chef Amy, and the entire staff of Primo, enough for ensuring our dinner for four was perfect. You may note I highlighted Primo has a great tasting menu. That is because Chef Amy worked with me to create the perfect tasting menu for my guests. Each dish split, individually plated for four, and then served by the team with perfection. I love eating in New York, Philadelphia and other large cities around the country and was pleasantly surprised our dinner and service rivaled many of the best. To take the time and effort to present our meal in such a way was going well beyond standard service. Drinks, Wine, Mussels, Salad, Lobster Ravioli, Chef’s Lasagna, Prime Steak, followed by Dessert and Coffee make pretty much the perfect meal for all. One suggestion, however, should you choose to do the same and create a custom tasting menu for your evening, you may want to consider tipping beyond the norm, as their efforts are truly worthy.

data.title: Terrible in all ways possible
data.text: went to a private party here....the food regular italian....nothing great, things i could have made at home....chef was walking around calling staff unpleasant names and yelling at them in the back.....one of the guys at the bar said the kitchen staff was stealing tips from waiters......at one point chef asked my friend how much he was tipping the bartenders.....very unprofessional and will not return....wish i could give zero stars

data.title: Descent food, but nothing truly remarkable other than the view. (kind of)!
data.text:
I had made reservations for a Thurs. night at 8:00 two months ahead of time.  I had requested a window view and was told that there would be no problem.  When we got there at 7:45, all the tables by the windows had been seated and to have one of them would take at least till 8:30.  There were only two tables open.  One by a wall, with a very little view, and another in the middle of the restaurant with a glimpse of the city.
     Luckily, we were there by 7:45 because be 7:50, two more people arrived at sat by the wall!
      That set the mood.  
      Then came the noise--especially from those who had been drinking.
      Then the food was average and a bit cold.
      Then dessert was a bit manipulated.  A dessert taster was actually several desserts at practically full price for each.  Either inexperience or a waitress wanting a bigger tip made this happen.
       Primo could be a great restaurant.  It has the location for it, but right now, they need to fix some internal problems.

data.title: Solid food, great staff, great views
data.text: The food is good, but know that your price includes the awesome views.  We went here to have a "special night out" experience and it did not disappoint.  The tiramisu and italian cream cake were excellent. So was the caesar salad.  Our main pasta dishes were good too.

data.title: Amazing Venue/amazing food
data.text: My husband and I visited Primo's because we know the new executive chef, Amy Carpenter who is an exceptional skilled chef and it was a perfect venue to capture a sunset. We weren't disappointed, the steaks were so tender, melted in your mouth good!  We also had appetizers, house salad and the lava cake for dessert!  We will be back, keep up the good work Chef Amy!

data.title: Sadly, Primo seems to have peaked!
data.text:
I went to Primo knowing that the founding chef has left, but we still wanted to try the restaurant.   Sadly our experience was pretty bad.

Food was mediocre to bad.  We both enjoyed the mixed salad, which was very large (enough for two people); but only one of us order the mixed salad, the other was supposed to be an insalata Caprese.   We didn't fuss, it was pretty good.

The mushroom risotto had such a heavy flavor of garlic that it was impossible to taste any mushrooms.  And while risotto should be well-cooked with lots of chicken stock, this rice was "al dente" (tough)... it was not cooked enough.   The meat lasagne was okay, but I may have had better at Olive Garden.  We were offered a gratis dessert rather than returning the food.  The chocolate lava cake is passable.

The service was also not very good.  I understand that there was a UT football game showing on all the TV screens, but the waiter messed up our orders and generally seemed inattentive.

All in all NOT a good experience.   We won't be returning.

data.title: Really happy to find this place!
data.text: Sort of lucked into finding this place. Didn't even know they had re-opened a restaurant in the Sunsphere.It's been closed for so long I was surprised when I went on Open Table and was able to book a table right after the Tennessee-Florida game.The seating is VERY limited but great view of the city with a nice small bar area and very quiet. Food was quite good and service was spot on. Price was in line with the other nice restaurants in the area.It appears they have valet parking on non-game nights , at least I saw a sign for it tucked away to the side.Got to believe that if the food quality holds up over time this will be a hard place to get a reservation for in the future. They open at 5 so this would be a great place to come after work for a drink and let the traffic thin out. Hope they can keep their numbers up to stay around for awhile.

data.title: Chef Bruce Bogartz has left Primo
data.text:
I read that Bruce has left, is going to cook for a popup restaurant called Tata for a couple of months, then have surgery.

I don't have info as to whether Primo will stay open, and if so, who will be the chef.  

I would be wary until the muddy water clears a bit.

data.title: great game-day spot at the bar
data.text: this place has been renovated and changed from Icon. fantastic place to watch UT games on Saturdays at the bar. Lots of good apps and drink specials, and it's never ever crowded and they have lots of tvs

data.title: Great food. Great atmosphere !!
data.text: My wife and I dined at Primos last night and had a great meal from the stuff mushroom appetizer to entrees. My wife had the filet mignon, cooked perfectly along with garlic potatoes and broccoli. I had the eggplant which was delicious. Samuel our server did a great job with wine recommendation and service. The chef/owner dropped by the table checking on our food which we appreciated.Beautiful view of Knoxville and the mountains in the background. Valet parking made it easy and was reasonable. When visiting Knoxville Primo will be at the top of my list in eating out.

data.title: A Bit of A Disappointment
data.text:
Last weekend I was in Knoxville with my BFF enjoying a girl's weekend, and we made the decision to have dinner at this highly-recommended restaurant.  We made reservations (as per advise of other reviewers), and were psyched to "taste the pictures" we'd been swapping vial email for the past few weeks.

We arrived on time for our 8pm reservation, and were told there was a slight wait.  We were happy to sit at the bar and order a few drinks before dinner, and the hostess told us it would be "about 10-15" minutes for a table to open up.  We saw great seats at the front window and asked to be seated in a specific area, and the hostess explained there were two couples ahead of us for that particular area.

I really wanted the great view of the city, so I was content to wait the 10-15 minutes.  As I watched a first, and a second couple get seated in the section we'd requested, I got excited knowing we were next.  After almost 30 minutes the hostess came to get us...and walked us to the opposite side of the restaurant.  Sure, it was a table near the window, but it wasn't the seating we'd been promised and had waited an extra 30 minutes to sit in.

At the EXACT same moment we were being seated, a table from the section we'd requested left, so I had my BFF pick up her drink and move to the other table.  I purposefully stood next to the table we'd requested until someone walked over and said, "Oh. Did you want this table?" 

When we were finally seated, I was excited to see the menu, and to ask the waiter about one of the dishes I'd seen coming out of the kitchen while waiting at the bar.  Our server had approximately five (5) tables in his section (with only 2 patrons per table).  We asked about the dish a couple two tables down had, and the server couldn't remember what it was.  We tried to describe it, and he couldn't definitely figure it out.  Rather than go check the ticket (or even just KNOW since he only had five tables and the couple was still eating), he suggested a different dish that we ended up ordering.

I will absolutely give Primo credit for getting the food to the table quickly.  That, and the bartenders (great drinks!), were the only highlights to my experience that evening. 

The pasta was just okay...honestly, a little bland.  Thinking I'd just spice it up with a little salt and fresh-cracked pepper, I looked around for our server.  He was incredibly busy with the other four tables.  So busy, in fact, that in the course of the next 10-15 minutes he passed by our table not once, not twice, not thrice...but FOUR times without asking about our food or if we needed anything.  

As politely as possible I explained that I'd only felt my initial taste of the pasta was "just okay," but might have been improved if I'd gotten salt and the offer of fresh-cracked pepper (come on, it's a "primo" pasta restaurant!) before my food got cold.  My BFF and I were splitting an entrée, and she ate a small portion of the pasta before just sitting back to enjoy the cocktails.  I absolutely wasn't in the mood to eat (and honestly, was fuming a little), so we just sent 3/4 of the pasta back to the kitchen and requested the check.

Our server was visibly confused as to my response to the food and service, but he recovered well and offered an apology for our experience.  I was thankful when the check came to the table that the server was gracious enough to comp the meal for the evening, leaving us with only our bar tab to resolve.

Will I go to Knoxville again? Absolutely.  It's a great city with amazing food, music, and booze galore.  Will I go to Primo again? Meh.

Honestly, I probably would have given this place a "2" if I'd had to pay and tip for the meal.

data.title: Best dinner in Knoxville
data.text:
Had a marvelous meal, great view, good wine. Easy to park with 

 an elevator ride to the top op the sphere, the restaurant  itself is very modern, looking out over the city.  Food is the chef's version of Italian, better than most in this area.  Just the right amount of seasoning.  Clams in Bloody Mary sauce was to die for.  Can't wait to go back

data.title: Great "special moments" place
data.text: We went for our anniversary.The food was delicious, the sunset was awesome and they make parking easy with their valet parking!

data.title: The best and only really contemporary Italian restaurant in Knoxville
data.text: Being Italian, and having lived there until few years ago, make me very picky about Italian food. Bruce Bogartz, the chef at Primo, is excellent in reproducing authentic Italian cuisine as I would find it in a good restaurant in Italy. He does that with the enormous handicap of not having access to fresh Italian ingredients...how he does it is a mystery...probably he is just a good chef! and sure is a great place to have excellent Italian food without having to fly overseas...I do recommend to take several small plates (they are not that small) and share them all, so you can have a full sampling of the menu.

data.title: great service and surprised by delicoius food
data.text:
First and foremost, this is one of the most welcoming, nice restaurant staffs we have ever interacted with. From the nice waiter who had too many tables but never let it show to the friendly greeting to the terrific bar staff. We walked up and felt to welcome; not a hint of pretension or annoyance from anyone even on a night they were understaffed and we showed without a reservation. 

The second great part was the food. Usually when one goes to an attraction-based restaurant you realize you are going for the fun of the attraction, not the quality of food. We were therefore particularly delighted that everything was delicious. I would return to this place even if it were located elsewhere. That said, having the nice view at a cute table that overlooked Knoxville was wonderful and we really enjoyed our evening here.

data.title: Delicious food!
data.text: I like Italian food! I went yesterday With my friends and it was great night. Everybody loved their food and the service was great. The only  bad thing was my boyfriend's pasta but besides that was perfect. We'll be back

data.title: Stay away!
data.text: The view was beautiful!  The food was disgusting.  We had polenta fries that were deep fried and served with a pico di Galo that was poorly diced and runny.  All three of us ordered something different - duck polenta - inedible.  Sent it back and the chef was nice enough to take it off our check.  I had the eggplant which was yummy.  Husband had the ribeye which he enjoyed.  The worst thing was that everything was covered in oil and made us sick burping and upset tummies all night.  Even the items that tasted good were not enjoyable.  There are plenty of clean, delicious places in Knoxville to go that don't give this view.  Go somewhere else for dinner and enjoy the view at the sunsphere from the observation deck.

data.title: Great Food
data.text: Have been to Primo twice in the last 2 months. Really good food and service. They now have valet parking which makes the experience much easier.

data.title: Spouse Birthday
data.text: If new to Knoxville, then the valet parking is a big plus. Chef Bruce Bogartz continues to amaze me with his blend of textures and flavors and wonderful sauces. With local corn at its peak, we shared his Sweet corn risotto with crawfish tails and green onion pesto; Sweet potato gnocchi with spinach, edamame and mushrooms; Angel Hair del Mare (lump crab, sweet corn, saffron butter) and finished off with local peach cobbler with pistachio gelato and coffee. Fantastic, as we watched the evening arrive over the Tennessee River through the windows of the 1982 Worlds Fair Sunsphere. Remarkable flavors, textures and aromas from arguably Knoxville's Best Chef. Service was the best!
